awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Morphosyntactic and Interpretive Dependency Formation in Agreement Attraction
awd_abstract_narration:
For typical adult native speakers, understanding sentences feels very easy. In fact, we know from prior research that comprehension is a highly complex mental process that requires speakers to coordinate sophisticated implicit knowledge about the structure of their language with the appropriate perceptual and memory operations under immense time pressure. While humans are remarkably skilled at this challenging task, they sometimes arrive at erroneous interpretations that are inconsistent with the linguistic input they received. Understanding the mechanisms that lead to misinterpretations in neurotypical adult native speakers is an important step towards a better understanding of the problems experienced by populations that have difficulties with language comprehension, such as second language learners or people with language disorders.

This project investigates to what extent memory retrieval errors contribute to misinterpretation in sentence processing. Language comprehension frequently requires establishing morphosyntactic and interpretive relationships between non-adjacent words, such that the earlier word has to be retrieved from memory. For example, in the sentence 'The boy next to the beautiful trees probably does not hear the music', the verb 'does' has to agree in number with the subject head 'boy', even though many words intervene between the subject head and the verb. Memory retrieval is susceptible to similarity-based interference. Therefore, previous research has shown that comprehenders are less likely to notice subject-verb agreement violations in the presence of a non-subject noun that matches the verb in number (e.g., 'The key to the cabinets are rusty'), presumably because sometimes the number-matching non-subject noun is misretrieved from memory instead of the target. Here the researchers will use methods of evaluating real-time language comprehension such as tracking eye movements during reading to investigate how misretrieval in subject-verb agreement impacts the interpretation of the sentence. Interference in memory retrieval has been linked to comprehension difficulties in unskilled readers and has been proposed as the primary source of processing differences between native speakers and second language learners.  A better understanding of how basic properties of memory retrieval can contribute to misinterpretations will help us understand how language comprehension is impacted for these less successful language users.

por.por_cntn:
In order to understand language, readers or listeners must frequently establish relationships between parts of the sentence that are not directly adjacent to each other. Such relationships are evident in the case of grammatical agreement; for example, in the sentence 'The key to the cabinets certainly is rusty', the verb 'is' has to agree in number with the head of the subject phrase ('key'). The frequency of these non-adjacent relationships in human language means that the memory system must play a crucial role in language comprehension.

We know from past work that memory retrieval in language is subject to errors of interference, for example leading people to erroneously perceive certain agreement-violating sentences as grammatical when there is an interfering number-matching 'attractor' ('The key to the cabinets are rusty'). The current project investigated whether these memory retrieval errors impact the system at a purely formal level (checking agreement) or whether they also interact with semantic relationships and change the reader or listener?s perception of what the sentence meant.

In a series of behavioral experiments, the project investigated how misretrieval of the attractor in checking agreement dependencies interacts with the interpretive dependencies that have to be formed between the same items. The results indicate that, for the most part, memory retrieval errors of agreement do not interact with the meaning of the sentence or change its interpretation. Even when comprehenders experience agreement attraction errors, they do not mistake the number-matching attractor for the thematic subject of the sentence. We also find no evidence that the notional number of the attractor (e.g. a singular noun phrase with a plural meaning like "the gang") or the plausibility of the attractor as a potential subject of the verb affect the likelihood of memory retrieval errors for agreement in comprehension. These results provide several key insights into the nature of agreement computation. First, they suggest that agreement attraction is at least usually the result of a low?level feature checking operation without any impact on the interpretation. Second, the results indicate that attraction in comprehension is not sensitive to semantic information that is irrelevant to the agreement dependency in the grammar.

This research was conducted by the student Co-I under the direction of the PI and formed the basis of the Co-I's doctoral dissertation. The project supported the training of two undergraduate research assistants in the fundamentals of conducting scientific research, and provided the student co-PI with an opportunity to develop her mentoring skills. The broader impacts of the results of the research lie in their contribution to our understanding of the architecture of the memory system underlying language comprehension, providing evidence for functional separation between representational levels of meaning and form in certain cases of memory retrieval, with implications that extend to memory processes in other domains. Interference in memory retrieval has been linked to comprehension difficulties in unskilled readers, and a better understanding of how basic properties of memory retrieval can contribute to interpretations that are not consistent with the linguistic input is likely to be beneficial for understanding how language comprehension is impacted for these less successful language users.
